medium_description_en: Detects domestic abuse (intimate partner violence) in women in primary care settings.

input_schema.name: hum
input_schema.label_en: Have you been humiliated or emotionally abused in other ways by your partner or your ex-partner?

input_schema.name: afraid
input_schema.label_en: Have you been afraid of your partner or ex-partner?

input_schema.name: rape
input_schema.label_en: Have you been raped or forced to have any kind of sexual activity by your partner or ex-partner?

input_schema.name: kick
input_schema.label_en: Have you been kicked, hit, slapped or otherwise physically hurt by your partner or ex-partner?

how_to_use.use_case_en: Do you use Humiliation, Afraid, Rape, Kick (HARK) and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

next_steps.advice_en: Do you use Humiliation, Afraid, Rape, Kick (HARK) and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

about.formula_en:
The HARK screening result is determined according to the following points:

Variable

Points

Within the last year…

Have you been humiliated or emotionally abused in other ways by your partner or your ex-partner?

0

about.more_info_en: A “yes” answer to any of the screening questions is considered a positive screening result.

Validation.text: Clark CJ, Renner LM, Wang Q, Flowers NI, Morrow G, Logeais M. Longitudinal trends in screening males and females for intimate partner violence as part of a systemic multi-specialty health system intervention. BMC Res Notes. 2021;14(1):344.

Feltner C, Wallace I, Berkman N, et al. Screening for intimate partner violence, elder abuse, and abuse of vulnerable adults: evidence report and systematic review for the US preventive services task force. JAMA. 2018;320(16):1688.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Sohal H, Eldridge S, Feder G. The sensitivity and specificity of four questions (Hark) to identify intimate partner violence: a diagnostic accuracy study in general practice. BMC Fam Pract. 2007;8:49.

creator_info.about_en: Hardip Sohal, MD, is a psychiatrist at the Department of Psychiatry at Fortis Hospital in Mohali, Punjab, India, which he established in 2001. He is credited with a vast study on the alcohol opiate dependent population and has given multiple lectures on the topic. Dr. Sohal’s primary research is focused on diagnosis and treatment of mental disorders in adults, adolescents, and children.
